content.title: Arteriovenous Fistula Maturation
content.description: The process by which a surgically created arteriovenous fistula develops adequate flow, diameter, and depth to support hemodialysis cannulation.
content.definition: AVF maturation is the physiologic remodeling of an AVF that allows it to support hemodialysis. The 'Rule of 6s' defines maturity: blood flow >600 mL/min, vein diameter >6mm, depth <6mm from skin, and length adequate for two-needle cannulation. Maturation typically requires 4-8 weeks but varies.

maturation_assessment: Arm elevation test: Fistula should collapse
Augmentation test: Should augment with distal compression
factors_affecting_maturation: Arterial inflow: Adequate arterial pressure and caliber
Patient factors: Diabetes, elderly, female sex
failure_to_mature: May respond to angioplasty, ligation of accessories

learning_objectives: Identify causes of failure to mature
clinical_pearls: Radiocephalic fistulas have highest maturation failure rate
Physical exam as accurate as ultrasound in experienced hands
Early referral allows time for maturation before dialysis need
Salvage procedures can rescue many non-maturing fistulas
